questions.text: I feel that I am making progress toward my goals every day.
When trouble comes, I can usually think of ways to handle it.
Some skills (such as running, public speaking, writing) won‚Äôt improve much no matter how hard I try.
I believe adversity can sometimes help personal growth.
When there is a difficult task, I prefer not to be the one who has to do it.
I dislike things that are new or frequently changing.
Once I start something, I tend to stick with it until it's finished.
Compared to results, I believe the process of doing something contributes more to growth.
When I receive bad news, my emotions tend to react more intensely than other people.
I often try to get rid of unnecessary thoughts in my mind.
I frequently need to restrain myself from wanting constant relaxation or entertainment.
Failure discourages me for a long time.
While working or studying, unrelated thoughts often pop into my mind.
I often find enjoyment in the things I do.
When I am forced to work under pressure, I feel irritated and very unwilling.
When I encounter a difficult problem with no guaranteed solution, I feel excited and happy.
I know clearly what I am working toward right now.
I believe I can effectively handle sudden events in life.
No matter how well or badly I perform, I never doubt my ability to learn.
After setbacks, I generally become more mature and experienced.
I dislike doing things when I am unsure whether I can complete them successfully.
I am uncomfortable doing things in unfamiliar environments.
I enjoy tasks that require me to give my full effort to complete.
Regardless of the outcome, I believe the effort I put into the process is worthwhile.
I can notice my emotional fluctuations as soon as they appear.
I often try not to think about or discuss things that bother me.
I frequently have to resist the temptation of delicious food.
It usually takes a long time for me to forget unpleasant experiences.
While working or studying, I can clearly hear background sounds like conversations or people pouring water.
As long as something feels rewarding, I‚Äôm willing to do it even without payment.
When facing pressure, I reflect on what I did to deserve it.
The more difficult something is, the more focused I become when facing it.

ui.title: Multi-Dimensional Entropy Self-Test
ui.subtitle: Please choose the option that best matches your situation for each question.
ui.shareCopyUnsupported: Your browser does not support copying images. Please use Download instead.

report.title: ‚ú® Multi-Dimensional Entropy Test Report ‚ú®
report.overallHint: In general, higher entropy indicates greater uncertainty and fluctuation in your system (life / mental state). Lower entropy reflects a more stable and orderly state. However, ‚Äúhigh / low‚Äù is not equal to ‚Äúgood / bad‚Äù ‚Äî it depends on your growth goals.
report.dimMetaHint: This scale is built on 16 related constructs (sense of purpose, self-efficacy, learning beliefs, positive cognition, challenge avoidance, resistance to change, grit, process orientation, emotional sensitivity, thought control, impulse inhibition, antifragility, focus, self-generated goals, stress tolerance, and adversity quotient). These are summarised into the five sub-dimensions above. Each dimension is scored from 1 to 5 to indicate its current strength. If one sub-dimension is about 25% higher or lower than your personal mean across the five, it can be treated as a relatively pronounced strength or weakness, and may be a good priority for your next round of reflection and practice.
report.overallDynamicHint: All scores and types only reflect your state right now. As your life stage and actions change, these results will also shift. They are better treated as a dashboard for ongoing tracking than as fixed labels about who you are.
report.closedExplainGrowth: Your overall mindset leans toward a *growth mindset*: lower scores indicate openness and a stronger belief that you can change through effort.
report.closedExplainFixed: Your overall mindset leans slightly toward a *fixed mindset*: higher scores indicate stronger attachment to existing views and being less willing to try new approaches.
report.resistExplainEfficient: You tend to show *efficient action*: lower scores indicate smoother execution and that your energy is more likely to be used on things that truly matter.
report.resistExplainInefficient: You tend to show *inefficient action* (internal resistance): higher scores indicate hesitation, second-guessing, emotional drain, and reduced efficiency.
report.dimClosedHint: Related constructs: sense of purpose, self-efficacy, learning beliefs, positive cognition.
report.dimBalanceHint: Related constructs: challenge avoidance, resistance to change.
report.dimInnerChaosHint: Related constructs: emotional sensitivity, thought control, impulse inhibition, antifragility.
report.dimEnergyBlurHint: Related constructs: focus, goal-setting, stress tolerance, adversity quotient.
report.credit: Questions and explanations are adapted from {bookLink} by {author}. This tool is provided solely for personal learning and reflection. Please contact me if you would like this content removed.

dolphin.name: Dolphin type (Growth + Efficient)
dolphin.summary: High openness with low internal resistance. You are more willing to step out of your comfort zone while keeping your cognitive energy focused on clear goals ‚Äì a configuration that combines strong growth with good efficiency.
points: High openness, low resistance: you stay curious about new things and are less constrained by fear or self-doubt.
Able to keep expanding your stretch zone by actively trying and exploring, accumulating experience and resources along the way.
Goals tend to be relatively clear, and it is easier for you to concentrate on important tasks.
More likely to gain satisfaction from the process itself, with a certain level of resilience when facing setbacks.

sloth.name: Sloth type (Growth + Draining)
sloth.summary: Your mindset is open and you can see a wider space for growth, but your actions are often slowed down by sensitive emotions and overthinking.
points: High openness, high resistance: willing to change, but the first step often feels very heavy.
Your goals are not completely vague, yet you frequently get stuck in cycles of ‚Äúthinking more‚Äù and hesitation.
Cognitive energy is easily scattered by various thoughts and by what others might think, so execution can be unstable.
You are more sensitive to details in the process and carry a higher emotional load, which makes it important to learn how to regulate pressure while taking action.

rhino.name: Rhino type (Fixed + Efficient)
rhino.summary: You put in effort and execute well, performing steadily in familiar fields, but your motivation to stretch or change direction is relatively limited.
points: Openness is lower, but you can maintain high-efficiency output on your existing path for a long time.
It is easy to gain a sense of safety from ‚Äúfamiliar hard work‚Äù, so there is less urgency to explore other directions.
Resources and abilities are mostly invested in known domains, and you are more cautious about unfamiliar paths.
If you can combine this efficiency with a more growth-oriented mindset and try modest experiments, there is often substantial potential for further development.

tunicate.name: Tunicate type (Fixed + Draining)
tunicate.summary: More inclined to hold on to the current state while also being easily drained by emotions and self-doubt, so both cognitive and action resources feel tight.
points: Openness is relatively low, and you are more likely to retreat to familiar patterns when faced with change or challenge.
Internal resistance to action is high, and a lot of energy can be consumed in negative thinking and emotional loops.
Long-term sense of direction may feel weak, making it hard to accumulate cognitive energy into concrete actions.
Once you start consciously lightening the load and taking small actions, even modest changes can bring noticeable improvements in how you feel.

report.labelWarning: The four animal types are only meant to help illustrate different combinations of the two main axes. They are not intended to label anyone in a fixed way. As situations and topics change, you may present very different entropy types at different times.

explain.closedGrowth: Your mindset leans toward a growth mindset: lower scores indicate openness and belief in self-improvement.
explain.closedFixed: Your mindset leans toward a fixed mindset: higher scores indicate adherence to existing views and resistance to change.
explain.resistEfficient: You tend toward efficient action: lower scores indicate smoother execution and better use of energy.
explain.resistInefficient: You tend toward inefficient action: higher scores indicate hesitation, emotional drag, and reduced effectiveness.

usage.summary: How should I use this scale?
usage.p1: It is recommended to take the test once before you start a new entropy-reduction action, as a baseline record.
usage.p2: While you are acting on a goal, you can re-test roughly once a month to see whether your total entropy and the two main axes (closedness / resistance to action) are trending down overall.
usage.p3: Rather than testing too frequently in a short period, it is more useful to use the scale to track longer-term trends ‚Äì whether total entropy is gradually decreasing and inner friction is easing.
usage.p4: If, under a certain course of action, your total entropy keeps rising noticeably for several months in a row, it may be a sign that the direction is not suitable and it is worth pausing to review and adjust.
